instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS: What is PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS? PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor to components that create power rails for the GPU. .

threads.title: 820-332 green light no power <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: Hello,  I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with liquid damage. I have never worked on one of these boards before. The only thing I can see visually is <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> which isn't looking too good nor is plane around it. I see what look like many little vias next to it which have lifted along with the res of the exposed circuit. Im wondering if this is even repairable because I'm not sure where any of them go. Is this even worth me getting a donor board for? I don't see any other damage anywhere on the board at all. Is this something that is common to fail and does it kill any other components along with it?

threads.title: 820-332 green light no power <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: Do you have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Any Voltage on S5, S3, or S0 Rails?

threads.title: 820-332 green light no power <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Magsafe remains orange even when battery is unplugged

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>   0.165V - 0.217V  diode mode it drops from 10.0 instantly to 0.3

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>       0.76V    diode mode 0.529

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>        0.1V    diode mode 12.16

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>        0.1V   diode mode 4.1

threads.title: 820-332 green light no power <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
That doesn't fare well for the GPU, but probably isn't the primary issue. 

Does this have a green light on the charger? 

What is the resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

threads.title: 820-332 green light no power <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
When connecting the magsafe the light is green for a few seconds and then turns orange.

17/18 is 4.4

27/28 is 22.0

threads.title: 820-332 green light no power <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> is obviously shorted. Start with replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> and pray the GPU survived.

threads.title: 820-332 green light no power <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: Ok. I don't have a donor board and ordered one but tis from China so god knows when it will get here. Louis if your open tomorrow could I stop by and buy a donor board or two from you?

threads.title: 820-332 green light no power <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: i barely have enough fro myself, and I can guarantee you they're all missing <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>

threads.title: 820-332 green light no power <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
No Title

This is what the area looks like once I removed it. All 6 pads have continuity. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> short still present. I can see the exposed copper for <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL> might be touching the exposed copper circuit for pad 1 and 2 on <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>. The <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL> copper seems pretty loose should I gently pry it off the <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR> p1 and p2 copper or leave it alone?

threads.title: 820-332 green light no power <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: Looks like a short in the board to me. It's pretty cremated around there.

threads.title: 820-332 green light no power <TRANSISTOR>Q8930</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
No Title

Yea burn is very deep. Believe it or not all that surface stuff was lose and even when I got to this point i was still scraping ash out of the board which was revealing more layers. RIP.
